Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 08:27AM dmayes wrote: Stacey,  I have jsut met with my onc, having been diagnosed in March this year.  I was all for the mastectomy - I have had a lumpectomy but if it meant tht the risks are lowered then I would also do it.  The sad news was he said it doesnt lower my risk!!  In fact, he said have the breast tissue is better, as if it comes they can remove then do chemo/radiation to remove.  If you had the mastectomy and it came - then ir might be in you chest wall and that is much worse.  See if you can get the MRI - or at least a CT scan will check your system  The BRCA test is a good one and you would be a good candidate given the family history.  I have no family history and I am only 41, so this beast isnt predictable - but is beatable.  I am learning that from al these lovely ladies and now my onc. My Onc put it a great way - he is in the job of living.  There is an "end" for all of us - that is a given and this doesnt make it anymore defined.  It is just another challenge that faces you every day.  So maybe put a regime of tests in place to assist in detecting - and each year that you clear that - celebreate your life! Cheers Debs PS - I am starting chemo on Mon 11th, scared yet OK with the fact that this is what kills it!

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2009 09:20PM dmayes wrote: Hi Deb, I had my lumpectomy/nodes removed on March 18 - take some senekot (sp) or prunes, etc - something to help your bowels - they tend to sleep with the anesthetic.  Drink lots of water.  Ask for the pain meds every 6-8 hours - better to keep it under control than try to be brave, not take them and then try to get on top of the pain.  I had mine pain meds for 5 days - but scar across the arm (15 nodes removed0 - all depends on how big that scar is.  Keep an eye on your drain too.  My drain was blocked with some fibres, so check that daily for any foreign materila in it - ask you doc what you should do if it appears to have stuff in it.  Mine started to weep at the skin when the stuff was in there - the doc in emergency was clueless!!!  Also keep your eye on your boob after the lumpectomy - I developed a seroma (fluid buildup) in the boob 4 weeks after surgery (apparently 80% of lumpectomys get these).  They had to drain it over a week with IV antibiotics every 8 hours - ask them about that.  They didn't tell me all the things they should have - so good luck and make sure you do your exercises - they help with the fluid and arm movement.  And get some rest - do not push/pull with that arm or carry heavy things - even if you feel better and think you can.   Get some good Vit e cream to rub into your scars about 3 weeks after surgery - ine are already less red and starting to look better.  Wishin you no nodes and clear margins - good luck and keep smiling - we are all here to help Regards  Debs  M
